question: I had a left lumbar laminectomy, foraminotomy,diskectomy, and nerveroot decompression, at left l5-s1 in mar 1994. I have contined to havesevere low back pain and left leg pain.  The MRI shows degenerativedisc disease at that location.  Have had numerous injections, therapy,with no success. Now using a back brace. My neurosurgeon said if thebrace helps considerbly, then he propably would do a spinal fusion.The brace helped reduce the pain, but you can't wear it all the time.One of my problems is that I have a right leg fusion(doesn't bend) andthe limp puts tremendous stress on the back. Would you give me youropinion and explain about a spinal fusion.  Also, I am a insulin dependentdiabetic.  Would this be a big problem concerning infection and healingafter the surgery.  The pain is unbearable, and medications are no longerworking.  I'm leaning toward the fusion.Thank you for your comments and help..______________________________________Dear Chuck,A small percentage of patients will continue to have problems after a lumbar discectomy.  Among these problems a patient may develop instability of the vertebrae at that level from removal of the disc.  This may cause chronic pain and disability.  Some of these patients with instability will benefit from a fusion.  Some will not.  It is difficult to identify those patients who will not improve after a fusion.A fusion in your case would carry an increased risk of complications due to your history of diabetes.  The risk would be to infection and not developing a solid fusion after surgery.  This risk is not astronomically higher than a patient without diabetes.  It is a little higher and not to the degree that should prevent a surgeon from recommending surgery.Speak to your surgeon about the risks and benefits of surgery and the odds of improvement in your situation to get a clear understanding of his goals with regard to your care.Good luck.
title: spinal fusion; patient with diabetes
